titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Day past in the usual anxiety of performing nothing. Evening at Mr: Scholten’s. Company not numerous and partly unknown to me. Quadrille. Most of the company disappeared before supper, table therefore very thin. Home not very late.

2. Striving the whole day very hard to write; and wrote scarce any thing. Met the Bielfeld’s & Mr: Midleton walking. Evening at the Play. Marquis de Tulipano. Burlesque Opera. Music of Paesiello; and very beautiful. Deux petits Savoyards.
3. Contrived at length with great pains to write a little. Several vessels going to different quarters at once. The object of existence, civil political and personal, not to be forgotten.

4. My brother went to Rotterdam, to celebrate the anniversary with our Countrymen there. Visit from Mr: Mersen this morning. From Mr: Brito, of congratulation upon the day. At the play this Evening, Euphrosine ou le Tyran Corrigé. Play monstrous & absurd; music admirable. faux talisman—comedy without music. Not out otherwise. Rainy weather through the day.

5. Rainy again part of the day. Industriously engaged till the Evening writing to the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr: Parker.— My brother returned this day just at dinner time. A little time still left for writing, to America. Walk at last this Evening. Time flies with a most unreasonable rapidity.

6. Writing again all the morning. Walk in the wood; alone. Immediately after dinner went in the Schuyt to Mr: Veerman’s, country seat; called Visch Lust near Leydsendam. Boat excessively full, and no room in the Roof. Found Mr: Dumas there; he came away immediately after. Walked in the Garden till about 9. They came with me then as far as the Village. Walked home. The distance about 5. Miles. About 11. at home.

7. Count Lowenhielm the Swedish Minister called and requested me to forward a Letter from him to Mr: Gervinus, the Prussian Chargé des Affairs at Paris to Mr: Monroe.— Dined at the Counts’. The french Representative Richard, the Generals Moreau, Golowkin; Dumonceau and MacDonald with the other usual company; The Vicomte de Roer and a Citoyen Brulé, the former an aid de Camp of La Fayette; left France with him, & was more fortunate in making his escape than his General. Brulé is one of the Secretaries of the Representatives; I had considerable conversation with him, being seated next him at table. We talked especially of the french Ministers in America Genet & Fauchet. He said that he was sometime since walking in the Thuileries, and met a person who went to America with Fauchet as his secretary. That on his expressing his surprize on finding him there, whom he supposed to be in America, the other said to him, “I am come home to tell you that the best thing you can do is to call home Fauchet and all the rest of us, and employ Genet again for he was really worth more than all of us put together.” He spoke himself well of Genet, as they all do at present. He did the same with respect to Fauchet, who Richard said, was introduced to public affairs too young, and had made some very bad bargains for grain.
To the play this Evening. L’isle enchantée; and l’amour mousse. Dull enough.
8. Writing principal part of the day. Evening at the concert; performed by the musicians of the french army; indifferent in general. There was however a very good violoncello, or base viol.

9. Continued very busy, writing without any performance. Reading this afternoon. finished reading the Henriade with the dissertations &c. Fail in punctuality even at my walk. I know not what becomes of time. Saw Mr: Paulus this morning.

10. Employed with nothing done. Evening at Baron Schubart’s. Company of Men, the same as last at Count Löwenhielm’s. Ladies Madame Scholten, without her husband, mirum! Madame Cneiff, and others not worth the noticing. Play’d at Quadrill. My lessons rather less expensive than heretofore. Supper pleasant enough. Card this day from Richard, and the Citoyen Pinsot, who styles himself Chargé des Affaires de France.— Walk with Mr Brito. Went to see the books to be sold next week.

11. Called three times this day on Mr: Van Zon but did not find him at home. Evening at the Play. Concert de la Rue Feydeau, an occasional piece in Vaudeville’s, very indifferent. And Les Visitandines. Walk in the morning alone.

12. Visit this morning, from Mr: Houghton of Boston, who has some property seized having introduced here in contraband unknown as he says to himself. Claimed my assistance. Saw Mr: Van Zon. recommended Mr: Houghton to Mr: Bourne. Wrote to Mr: Allis, Rotterdam, relative to Mr: Roach’s vessel. Long letter to Mr: De Wolf.
13. Attended the sale of books the whole day, purchased a considerable number. Walk in the Evening alone. Music at home.

14. Walking in the street in the morning, met W. Clark. In the afternoon W. Amory called on me; said he was a prisoner of War to the french army, and was desirous if possible to be liberated; that he had been sick in the hospital near Rotterdam, these ten months, and being now upon the recovery, and having an opportunity to go home, he was very anxious to obtain a discharge. I wrote immediately to the Representative Richard, a card, requesting to know when I could speak with him this day. Towards evening his Secretary Brulé called and told me that Richard would be at home the remainder of the day, and would see me at the hour most convenient to myself. I went immediately afterwards, and stated to the Representative the circumstances of Amory’s story as he had told them to me; told him that I knew him personally to be an American, and was much acquainted with his family, which is highly respectable. He said that the discharge should be granted without the least difficulty, that it would be given with much pleasure as a compliance with the request of the Minister from a friend and ally of France, and if I would send the person to him in the morning with a line mentioning his name, and that he is the person concerning whom I had now spoken, he would immediately give the order necessary for his discharge.

15. Amory called here again early this morning; I gave him the letter for the Representative Richard, and about an hour afterwards he returned, with an order from him for the discharge with permission to return to America. I then observed to Amory, that it was I supposed meant simply as authorizing him to go home, and it was perhaps expected that he should not go to England. He said he certainly should not, and his only wish was to return to his own Country. Called on Mr: Quarles the Greffier with a note upon the subject of the prohibition upon the exportation of arms. He said he presumed there would be no difficulty in the matter, but that in point of form, it would be proper to present a memorial to the President of the States General, which I told him I would do with the greatest pleasure; the form of the thing being altogether
immaterial to me. Quarles is Dutchman all over, and prides himself upon it. It is possible, that with his manners very unpolished, and an appearance of very little cultivation or natural force of understanding, there are certain talents possessed by him; if so they are more of intrigue, than of any other character, & they are assuredly not brilliant.

Clarke dined with us, and we had much conversation upon our old affairs and our own Country. Baron Rehausen called here in the afternoon. Went to the concert given again by the band of music belonging to the french army. Not remarkably pleased Ripley was here this morning.

16. Presented this morning two memorials to the President of the States General Mr: Kempenaar, one upon the subject of the prohibition to export military arms and the other relative to the admission of Consuls from the United States into the Dutch Colonies.— Captain Simeon Spring of Boston was here. Met the two Bielfeld’s walking this forenoon. Evening at the play. Alexis et Justine, music indifferent. La Fausse Magie. Very good.
17. Attended the sale in the morning, made some purchases. Reading in the afternoon. Walk in the wood in the Evening. Rainy day.

18. At the sale a few minutes. At Mr: Parker’s, and sat for the miniature. Dined at Mr: Moliere’s. Monsr: & Made: Durieu. He is employed in the french army, and expresses his dissatisfaction with the present order of things more openly than any other I have yet seen.— Evening at the play. Raoul Sire de Corequi. Arlequin toujours Arlequin. essentially stupid.

19. Visit from Mr: Hogendorp a Dutch Gentleman, who has some idea of going to America, and who came to request information relative to the Country. From Mr: Houghton again relative to his affair; with Mr: Van Zon. Mr: Houghton dined with us. Walk in the wood towards the Evening; found it full of company.

20. Visited Mr: Paulus in the morning, and conversation with him upon our affairs. He was neither cordial, nor remarkably civil. I was tempted several times to say things which would mortify him without giving him the right to take offence. It is a temptation that should always be resisted. There is no kind of offence so malevolent as that which cannot discover itself. Was tolerably cautious therefore. Mr: Paulus was not so.— Saw Mr: Van Son and Mr: Houghton in the course of the day. Evening at Mr: Dumas’s.— Saw Mr: Masezi there. Madam left me with the old Gentleman, most of the Evening.
21. Walk in the wood: met Mr: Midleton. Evening at the Play. L’Epreuve Villageoise, good music. La Dot, not remarkable. Rainy Evening.

22. Writing to the Secretary of State. It becomes something like drudgery to be obliged to write perpetually without receiving any letters in return. C. Bielfeld called to see me this afternoon. Walked with him in the wood. He thinks of going to America. Sent him a letter for Mr: Beeldemaker at Rotterdam

23. Walk in the morning. Dined at Mr: Van Son’s, with all his family. Walk in the wood towards evening. Music. Read the Spectateur Francois pendant la Revolution; a work of great indifference. With Mr: Brito in the Voorhout.

24. My brother went to Rotterdam. Visit from Mr: Schermerhorn. He dined with me; went to the play in the Evening. Directeur dans l’embarras, and Les Visitandines, last performed better than it has been before. Rainy day.
25. My brother returned this morning from Rotterdam. Books received from the sale. Read the last memoirs of Dumouriez. Rainy great part of the day. Walk this Evening.
26. Writing to America. Read the appel a l’impartiale posterité by Madame Roland— Rainy day. Walk in the Evening.

27. Walk in the wood towards night. Evening at Mr: d’Araujo’s.— Comtesse Dahlberg, and her Daughter. Madame Rodoin and another Brabançon Lady. General Dumonceau. Messrs: Löwenhielm & Schubart, Fagel, Spaen, Middleton, Levsen & Reuterswerd, and a french emigrant, who told me that his father mother, and all his family had perished by the Guillotine. Conversation with Mr: Levsen, & with Mr: Spaen; agreeable; and the evening without cards. Count Löwenhielm told, offered to propose me as a member of the Grande Societé.— I thanked him; but know not why he made me the offer.

28. Read some french pamphlets. Short walk before dinner. At the play this Evening. They shut up for a fortnight. Les deux Espiegles, not remarkably good. Le Marquis de Tulipano. House full. met Bielfeld there.
29. Writing to my father. Bielfeld. Walk with him: french pamphlets encore.
30. As yesterday. Letter to my mother walk alone. In the Voorhout &c.
31. Letters from America. My regular course broken. Nothing to do or say.
